title: 'Britain's worst troll' jailed for hour-long Facebook Live rant about victim
text:

A serial online abuser has been jailed for an hour-long Facebook Live rant.

Stewart McInroy - believed to be the worst troll in the UK - flouted a restraining order three times, which a judge ruled was a persistent campaign of abuse.

The 28-year-old has been jailed at least four times previously for trolling.

He once told a BBC documentary he was "addicted" to abusing people online.

This time he went on a 56 minute Facebook Live tirade, revealing where his victim lived.

He also messaged the woman twice on Facebook - flouting a restraining order.

(Image: Newcastle Chronicle)

She told the court it had seriously impacted her mental health, forcing her to move house.

McInroy, of Cupar, Scotland, admitted the offences.

He was jailed for two years at Newcastle Crown Court last Friday.

The addict will be allowed back on social media after release, but banned from contacting the victim.

The court heard he had not messaged her since the abuse.

McInroy - who has more than 30 previous convictions - has reportedly been a model prisoner.

In August 2014, the serial offender was jailed for sending sick messages to the family and friends of missing man Allan Bryant Jr.

He falsely claimed he had taken Mr Bryant hostage and "brutally tortured and murdered him".

Mr Bryant has never been found.

Weeks after being released the trolling addict launched a campaign of abuse against his ex-girlfriend.

(Image: Getty Images)

He was jailed in March 2015 for saying he would burn down her house - and harm a child and a dog - if she didn't speak to him.

In 2017, he was back in jail for abusing and stalking a woman the day after he was released from jail.

The oddball also targeted Mr Bryant Jr's family once again in 2018.

He was handed an eight month prison term for peppering the missing man's father and sister with Facebook messages.

In September 2018, McInroy was attacked by members of a paedophile hunting group - Wolf Pack Hunters UK.

He had sent the vigilante group disgusting Facebook messages about child abuse.

They tracked him down and attacked him at a bus stop in Edinburgh.

The group was banned from carrying out any vigilante operations for two years at Edinburgh Sheriff Court on October 3.
description: Stewart McInroy, 28, from Cupar in Scotland, once told a BBC documentary he was "addicted" to abusing people online
